communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Essex county community justice support centers
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

- Any and all documents related to the Essex county sheriff’s department’s operations of Essex county community justice support centers since 2020
- Any and all communication between Massachusetts trial courts, Essex county sheriff’s office, and the community justice support centers in Lawrence and Havervill) since 2020
- Any and all documents pertaining to the Essex County sheriff offices related to pretrial services, diversion, and detention since 2020.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Maya Chandrakasan

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The New Jersey Attorney General Law Enforcement Directive No. 2022-12 regulating the use of Automated License Plate Recognition (ALPR) Technology provides in Section 2.3 that jurisdictions must share with the State ALPR Coordinator the camera name and location of installed or relocated fixed ALPR units. 

I am seeking a list, roster, report/s, datasets or other documents identifying which New Jersey jurisdictions have ALPRs.

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting information from the Office of the Executive Secretary concerning records of reimbursements for court-appointed counsel. Specifically, I am seeking:

The total count of reimbursements to counsel for court-appointed cases.
The total amount paid for these reimbursements.

I would like this data split by court where counsel was appointed. I would like this data provided on a monthly basis, if available, between January 2010 and December 2024. If monthly data is not available, yearly totals are acceptable. 

If possible, I also request that the data be separated by case type (misdemeanor vs. felony) within each court.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Please be advised, the District is currently investigating whether the requested records exist and/or are accessible under FOIL.  We anticipate providing you with a response on or before September 17, 2024. If such records exist and/or are accessible under FOIL, you will be advised as to the payment of fees, if applicable.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Tom Chris Korologos (April 6, 1933 – July 26, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Republican political adviser and ambassador Tom Chris Korologos (April 6, 1933 – July 26, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/07/us/politics/tom-korologos-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street
communications.communication:
Date: August 13, 2024

City of Aurora
15151 E. Alameda Parkway
Aurora, CO 80012

Attn: Records Department, Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel

Subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request – Code Enforcement Activity, Coordination with City Officials, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

NOTICE: This request involves specific records from multiple departments within the City of Aurora, including the Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, and Legal Counsel. Please read carefully and direct the request to the appropriate offices.

Dear Records Custodian,

Under the provisions of the Colorado Open Records Act (CORA), C.R.S. § 24-72-201 et seq., I hereby request access to and copies of records held by the City of Aurora related to the code enforcement activity at the apartment complex located at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO 80010, on Tuesday, August 13, 2024, starting around 7:30 AM. This request pertains specifically to the activities and communications involving the Code Enforcement Office, the City Manager’s Office, and the City’s Legal Counsel.

Records Requested

For the purpose of this request, I seek the following records:

	1.	Inspection Reports:
All reports generated in connection with the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street on the specified date. This includes inspection findings, any observed violations, and notes on follow-up actions or recommendations for further enforcement.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: These documents are public records as defined by C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a), with a presumption of openness as established in People v. Thompson, 181 Colo. 194, 509 P.2d 592 (1973).
	2.	Notices of Violation and Enforcement Actions:
Copies of all notices of violation, orders, or other formal enforcement actions issued by the Code Enforcement Office as a result of the inspection at the above location. This includes any communications with property owners or management regarding required corrective actions.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: Notices and enforcement actions are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The Colorado Supreme Court has supported the public’s right to access these records in Freedom Newspapers, Inc. v. Tollefson, 961 P.2d 1150 (Colo. 1998).
	3.	Internal and External Communications:
All communications related to the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street, including:
	•	Internal communications within the Code Enforcement Office regarding the planning, execution, and follow-up of the inspection.
	•	Communications between the Code Enforcement Office and the City Manager’s Office discussing the enforcement activity, any anticipated legal issues, or coordination efforts.
	•	Communications between the Code Enforcement Office and the City’s Legal Counsel, including discussions on potential legal implications, enforcement strategies, or responses to inquiries.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: These communications are considered public records under C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I). Transparency in government operations is a key principle supported by the U.S. Supreme Court in NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978).
	4.	Email Metadata:
Detailed metadata for all emails related to the above communications, including but not limited to:
	•	Sender and recipient information.
	•	Date and time stamps.
	•	Subject lines.
	•	Descriptions or filenames of any attachments.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: Email metadata is part of the public record under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(7)). This has been affirmed in cases such as O’Neill v. City of Shoreline, 170 Wash. 2d 138 (2010), where metadata was deemed necessary for transparency.
	5.	Photographs and Video Recordings:
Any photographs or video recordings taken during the code enforcement inspection at 1568 Nome Street, including those documenting conditions, violations, or interactions with property representatives.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office.
Legal Basis: Visual records created by government employees during official duties are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I)). The importance of these records for public accountability was highlighted in ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012).
	6.	Documents and Communications Regarding Media Staging Area:
All documents, memos, or communications related to the designation or use of a media staging area during the code enforcement activity at 1568 Nome Street. This includes any directives or guidelines for media access, communications regarding media presence, and decisions to restrict or manage media coverage.
Departments Involved: Code Enforcement Office, City Manager’s Office, Legal Counsel.
Legal Basis: Records related to media access during public operations are subject to public disclosure under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The U.S. Supreme Court in Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555 (1980), underscored the importance of public and media access to government activities.

Request for Segregable Non-Exempt Portions

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). The principle of releasing non-exempt portions is well-established in Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973).

Preservation of Records

Please be advised that you are legally obligated to preserve all records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court emphasized the prohibition against unlawful withholding, redaction, or destruction of records in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980).

Fee Waiver Request

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest, contributing significantly to public understanding of government operations. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such a waiver is justified.

If the fee waiver is not granted and there are anticipated charges exceeding $200, please notify me before processing the request.

Public Availability of Communications

Please note: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing messages, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Correspondence in relation to this request will be published immediately on the platform.

As required by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
MuckRock.com

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). The principle of releasing non-exempt portions is well-established in Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973). 

Preservation of Records 

Please be advised that you are legally obligated to preserve all records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court emphasized the prohibition against unlawful withholding, redaction, or destruction of records in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980). 

Fee Waiver Request 

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest, contributing significantly to public understanding of government operations. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such a waiver is justified. 

If the fee waiver is not granted and there are anticipated charges exceeding $200, please notify me before processing the request. 

Public Availability of Communications 

Please note: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing messages, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Correspondence in relation to this request will be published immediately on the platform. 

As required by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)). 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, 
Jordan Lassiter 
Independent Investigative Journalist 
MuckRock.com

title: Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024
communications.communication:
Date: August 13, 2024

Aurora Police Department
15001 E. Alameda Parkway
Aurora, CO 80012

Attn: Records Department

Subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request – Police Presence, Code Enforcement Coordination, and Media Staging Area at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO on August 13, 2024

Dear Records Custodian,

Under the provisions of the Colorado Open Records Act (CORA), C.R.S. § 24-72-201 et seq., and relevant federal transparency laws, I hereby request access to and copies of records held by the Aurora Police Department related to the police presence at the apartment complex located at 1568 Nome Street, Aurora, CO 80010, on Tuesday, August 13, 2024, starting around 7:30 AM.

Records Requested

For the purpose of this request, the records I seek include, but are not limited to:

	1.	Incident Reports: All reports generated in connection with the police activity at the above location and time.
Legal Basis: Under CORA, public records include any writings made, maintained, or kept by the state or its agencies, including incident reports (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)). In People v. Thompson, 181 Colo. 194, 509 P.2d 592 (1973), the court held that such records are presumptively open to the public.
	2.	Internal Memos, Emails, and Communications: All internal communications, including memos, emails, and other correspondences, related to the planning, execution, or follow-up of the police presence at this location. This specifically includes:
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the City of Aurora Code Enforcement Office.
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the City Manager’s Office.
	•	Communications between the Aurora Police Department and the Aurora City Council members.
Legal Basis: Emails and internal memos are public records under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I)). The U.S. Supreme Court has emphasized the importance of transparency in government operations in NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978).
	3.	Email Metadata: Detailed metadata for all emails related to the above communications, including but not limited to:
	•	Sender and recipient details.
	•	Date and time stamps.
	•	Subject lines.
	•	Attachments and their descriptions (if applicable).
Legal Basis: Metadata is considered a part of the public record under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(7)). In O’Neill v. City of Shoreline, 170 Wash. 2d 138 (2010), the court ruled that metadata associated with emails is subject to disclosure as part of the public record.
	4.	Body-Worn Camera Footage: All body-worn camera footage from officers present at the scene during the specified time.
Legal Basis: Body camera footage is considered a public record under C.R.S. § 24-72-303. Court decisions such as ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012), highlight the public’s interest in transparency and accountability in police actions.
	5.	Dispatch Audio: Recordings of all 911 calls and dispatch communications related to this incident.
Legal Basis: Dispatch audio is subject to disclosure under C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)(a)(I). In City of Colorado Springs v. White, 967 P.2d 1042 (Colo. 1998), the Colorado Supreme Court confirmed that such records must be made available unless specifically exempt.
	6.	Drone Footage: Any drone footage captured during the operation at this location.
Legal Basis: Drone footage falls under the same public record criteria as other visual recordings made by law enforcement (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The New York Times Co. v. DOJ, 756 F.3d 100 (2d Cir. 2014), reinforces the need for transparency in government surveillance activities.
	7.	Documents, Memos, or Communications Regarding the Media Staging Area: Any records related to the designation or use of a staging area for the media during the operation at the above location. This includes directives related to restricting media access or removal of the media from the area.
Legal Basis: Records regarding media staging areas fall under public access under CORA (C.R.S. § 24-72-202(6)). The U.S. Supreme Court in Richmond Newspapers, Inc. v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555 (1980), affirmed the public and media’s right to access government proceedings, which extends to law enforcement activities in public spaces.

Request for Segregable Non-Exempt Portions

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with C.R.S. § 24-72-204(3)(a). In Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973), the court established the principle that agencies must provide detailed justification for each exemption and release any segregable portions of records.

Preservation of Records

Please note your obligation under the law not to destroy any records potentially responsive to this request. The U.S. Supreme Court in Kissinger v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 445 U.S. 136, 150 (1980), emphasized that any withholding, redaction, or destruction of responsive records without proper justification constitutes a violation of FOIA and is subject to litigation.

Fee Waiver Request

Enclosed is a letter requesting a fee waiver for the processing of this request. As an independent investigative journalist associated with MuckRock.com, I believe that the information I seek is in the public interest and its disclosure contributes significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government. Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), such information warrants a fee waiver.

If the enclosed waiver is not accepted and there are any potential charges in excess of $200 associated with fulfilling my request, please inform me in advance.

Public Availability of Communications

Please be aware: All communications related to this request, including incoming and outgoing communications, will be publicly available on MuckRock.com. Additionally, any correspondence in relation to this request will be instantly published on the platform.

As stipulated by CORA, I look forward to your response within the statutory time frame of three business days (C.R.S. § 24-72-203(3)(b)).

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
MuckRock.com

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Ohio SOS Noncitizen Voting Purge 08.12.24
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Ohio Freedom of Information Act and the National Voter Registration Act, Documented makes the following request for copies of records:

1. A record of all voters removed or inactivated based on non-citizenship, or whose registration status was otherwise changed based on noncitizenship;  
2. All communications between any government agencies, including counties, regarding such removal, inactivation, or other change in status;
3. All data supporting the reasons for each such removal, inactivation, or other change in status;
4. All communications with those voters who were removed, inactivated, or whose registration status was otherwise changed;
5. All communications related to Secretary of State Frank LaRose’s announcement of the removal of “499 non-citizen registration”, as well as all communications pertaining to LaRose’s STATEWIDE VOTER REGISTRATION INTEGRITY AUDIT.

Please provide all responsive records from January 1, 2024, through the date the search is conducted.

Please note that the National Voter Registration Act requires that states make available for public disclosure “all records concerning the implementation of programs and activities conducted for the purpose of ensuring the accuracy and currency of official lists of eligible voters[.]” 52 U.S.C. § 20507(i)(1). 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. Additionally, we request a fee waiver for this request. I would prefer the request filed electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Please confirm receipt of this request. ​​Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Victoria Cadostin

title: NPS Chris Ryan Communications To Del Rio Rotary Club

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NPS Chris Ryan Communications To Del Rio Rotary Club
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any record of communication between National Park Service, NPS Amistad, NPS Chris Ryan, and Del Rio Rotary Club between January 2015 and July 2024.
Any record of government resources or assets (including hours worked or volunteered) offered, gifted, loaned, or otherwise provided to Del Rio Rotary Club between January 2015 and July 2024.
Any record of communication of requests, approval, or denial given by NPS authorizing NPS Amistad Superintendent Chris Ryan to hold the position of "Director of Del Rio Rotary Club".
Any record of ethics complaints made against NPS Amistad Superintendent Chris Ryan between January 2015 and July 2024.

National Park Service includes but is not limited to; any office, employee, internal database, email system, paper or digital records, mobile devices, or computer systems utilized within the service to submit, review, discuss, track, or investigate complaints; including but not limited to the offices of Ethics, Employee Relations, Regional Office, Chief Rangers Office, Regional Superintendents Office, EEO, Safety Manager, 16-E, ISB, IMARS.

Any record includes but is not limited to: electronically submitted complaints, phone call logs, recordings, transcripts, investigations, mitigations, determinations.
Communications include but is not limited to any digital or paper record, emails, text messages, or phone calls, received or sent by the National Park Service or any of its employees.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Veritas Oversight

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NPS Complaints against Joe Roberts
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any complaints received by the National Park Service regarding their employee Joe Roberts during his tenure as Chief Ranger of Padre Island National Seashore. Include any dispositions and final determinations.
Any record of investigation conducted by the National Park Service regarding their employee Joe Roberts relating to sexual assault, sexual harassment, harassment, discrimination, adverse conduct. Include any dispositions and final determinations.
Any record of disciplinary personnel action taken by the National Park Service regarding their employee Joe Roberts. Including any dispositions, final determinations, or memos.
Copy of SF-50 for National Park Service employee Joe Roberts.

National Park Service includes but is not limited to; any office, employee, internal database, email system, paper or digital record, mobile device, or computer system utilized within the service to submit, review, discuss, track, or investigate complaints; including but not limited to the offices of Employee Relations, Regional Offices, EEO, Safety Manager, 16-E, ISB, IMARS.
Complaints include but is not limited to any digital or paper record received by the National Park Service or any of its employees, relating to: harassment, threats, retaliation, assault, intimidation, discrimination, safety, adverse conduct or performance, or any other violation of administrative policy, ethics, safety, 36 Code of Federal Regulations, any violation of criminal law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Veritas Oversight

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Civil Asset Forefitures
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records related to civil asset forfeiture actions conducted by the Virginia State Police from January 1, 2024, to June 30, 2024.

Specifically, I am seeking:
1. A list of all civil asset forfeiture actions
2. The value of assets seized in each action
3. The reason for each seizure
4. The outcome of each action (if resolved)

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Gabriel Garcia.

communications.subject: Your Virginia State Police public records request #24-6897 has been opened.
communications.communication:
Virginia State Police ************************************************************************ Your record request #24-6897 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for your request to the Virginia Department of State Police. The Department will work to process your request and make a response to you according to the nature of the request. Additionally, the Department may make reasonable charges not to exceed the actual cost incurred in accessing, duplicating, supplying, or searching for the requested records. If you would like a cost estimate please let us know immediately when you receive this message. PLEASE NOTE: You must be logged into NextRequest PRIOR to viewing all future emails that contain messages with instruction. As the requester, you can always see the status of your request by signing into the Virginia State Police portal. If you haven't already signed in, you may need to activate or setup your account to get started. Once your account is activated, you can communicate directly with the Virginia State Police through NextRequest. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Virginia State Police.

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Policy documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any policy manual, employee procedure manual, or folder of collected policies which guide police operations. This may be one document with many policies, or all policies collected.

The original format of the documents is acceptable (PDF, .doc, .txt, etc).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Chamberlain

communications.subject: RE: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Policy documents
communications.communication:
Mr. Chamberlain,

    You have reached the Right-to-Know Officer for the Borough of Conway.  The Conway Police Department is no longer in existence.  You will need to reach out to the Beaver Valley Regional Police Department Right-to-Know Officer for your inquiry.  I am not able to help you with your request due to it is not affiliated with the Borough of Conway.  I would also recommend using the PA State Right-to-Know Form when you submit your request.

Sincerely,

Margie Nelko
Conway Borough Secretary/Treasurer
(724) 869-5550
mnelko@conwaypa.org

communications.subject: Automatic reply Re: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Policy documents
communications.communication:
PLEASE NOTE:   We do  not accept reports via email. If you have been a
victim of a crime, or a witness to a crime, please call 412-268-2323
immediately!

If you're emailing with regard to a room opening, we understand your
request is very important and we will give it the necessary attention
to accommodate your needs.  They are added to our daily roll call and
handled during scheduled opening times. Due to the  volume of
requests, we typically do not respond to emails regarding openings or
closings.

If you're emailing a request for a specific person, the email will be
forwarded to that party and you should expect to hear from them at
their earliest convenience.


 Thank you,


 CMUPD Communications
-- 
 Carnegie Mellon University Police
4551 Filmore Street.
Suite 199
Pittsburgh PA 15213
P 412-268-2323 Emergency
   412-268-6232 Non-Emergency
F 412-268-6437
campuspd@andrew.cmu.edu
